title: 103_s1661
content: The "Worker Protection Warnings Act of 1993" is referenced in the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. The Congress finds that the absence of uniform warnings for personal protective equipment for occupational use causes confusion among employers and employees, leading to increased worker exposure to workplace injuries and illnesses. Additionally, the lack of Federal standards for these warnings leaves questions about their adequacy to be determined by inconsistent State requirements. The absence of Federal standards for warnings on personal protective equipment for occupational use leads to confusion among employers and employees, increasing the risk of workplace injuries and illnesses. This lack of uniform standards places an undue burden on interstate commerce in such equipment. The purpose of this Act is to enhance workplace safety by establishing uniform warnings for personal protective equipment and preempting any conflicting State standards. SEC. 5. UNIFORM WARNINGS FOR PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT FOR OCCUPATIONAL USE. Section 6 (29 U.S.C. 655) is amended to include a new subsection requiring the Secretary, in consultation with the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, to establish uniform warnings for personal protective equipment for occupational use within 12 months of enactment. Personal protective equipment refers to gear for worker protection in the workplace. The final regulation establishes uniform warnings for personal protective equipment for occupational use, defining personal protective equipment as gear for worker protection in the workplace and warnings as any statement related to safety. The final regulation establishes uniform warnings for personal protective equipment for occupational use, defining personal protective equipment as gear for worker protection in the workplace. The term 'warning' refers to any statement directing actions or procedures related to the use of personal protective equipment that, if not followed, may result in personal injury or death to the user. Each standard promulgated under this regulation shall prescribe guidelines for personal protective equipment. Each standard issued under the regulation for personal protective equipment must include warnings that direct actions or procedures related to the equipment's use, with non-compliance potentially leading to personal injury or death. The regulation also specifies how manufacturers should communicate these warnings to employers. Each standard promulgated for personal protective equipment must include the full text of warnings and specify how manufacturers should communicate these warnings to employers. Employers are required to communicate these warnings to employees and provide training on the proper use of the equipment. The standard for personal protective equipment requires employers to communicate warnings to employees, provide training on proper use, and specify consequences of not following warnings. Effective 6 months after publication in the Federal Register. The standard for personal protective equipment mandates employers to communicate warnings, provide training on proper use, and specify consequences of non-compliance. Effective 6 months after publication in the Federal Register. Exemptions apply for warnings on equipment placed in interstate commerce before the standard's effective date, unless communicated by the manufacturer or seller. The Secretary considers various factors when promulgating standards for personal protective equipment, including manufacturer experience with warnings and communication methods, worker opinions, and input from experts and organizations like the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health. The Secretary considers factors like manufacturer experience, worker opinions, and expert input when promulgating standards for personal protective equipment. SEC. 6. PREEMPTION. In amending Section 4 and Section 18 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act, Congress clarifies its intent to regulate warnings for personal protective equipment and prohibits states from establishing conflicting standards after federal regulations are in place. After federal regulations are in place, no State or political subdivision may establish conflicting standards for personal protective equipment. The Secretary cannot approve a State plan that contradicts federal standards. The Secretary cannot approve a State plan that includes requirements different from federal occupational safety and health standards.
